entry.title: Combined summary - Bitcoin Core 0.12.0 release candidate 1 available
entry.summary: not set high enough. The context revolves around the concept of pruning in the Bitcoin ecosystem, specifically block pruning and the minimum storage quota required for it. The speaker questions why this is necessary if block data is not served to other nodes. It is revealed that the reason for the minimum storage quota is to allow reorgs up to 288 blocks deep even when pruning. The discussion also covers confusion around the need to specify a value for N while enabling pruning. The release notes were edited to explain why N must be given and what a safe value of N is, as well as mention whether there is an auto setting for N to ensure it chooses a safe value on its own.Bitcoin Core version 0.12.0rc1 binaries are now available on the official website of Bitcoin. This is a release candidate for a new major version release that brings new features, bug fixes, and other improvements. The release candidate will undergo testing before it becomes an official release. The update is expected to bring significant changes to the Bitcoin protocol, including faster transaction processing times, an updated fee estimation system, and improved privacy features.In a discussion regarding block pruning in Bitcoin, Wladimir J. van der Laan suggested advertising the feature in the new release notes. The RC2 changelog now includes instructions on enabling block pruning by setting prune= on the command line or in bitcoin.conf, with N representing the number of MiB allotted for raw block and undo data. A user expressed confusion over the need to specify a value for N, as they believed pruning should be a boolean on/off flag that automatically computes the natural size of the dataset based on the final amount of unspent coins. They requested further explanation in the release notes, including why N must be given, a "safe" value for N, and whether there is an "auto" setting for N. Satoshi's paper refers to UTXO pruning, while Pieter Wuille's "ultraprune" has been part of Bitcoin Core for more than three years. Block pruning, on the other hand, is not mentioned in that paper because nodes store historical blocks merely for administrative purposes. The only reason nodes store historical blocks at all is to serve it to other nodes. Therefore, right now, pruning nodes don't serve block data at all as it would require a change to the P2P protocol. A user can enable block pruning by setting prune= on the command line or in bitcoin.conf, where N is the number of MiB to allot for raw block & undo data.Wladimir J. van der Laan confirmed that pruning has been tested for almost half a year and will be included in the upcoming release of Bitcoin Core version 0.12. However, he also noted that users should still backup their wallets as there is always a possibility of issues with syncing between the wallet and blockchain. On January 18, 2016, Wladimir J. van der Laan announced the first binary release that contained block pruning functionality, which had been tested in git for almost half a year. Though he stated it was highly unlikely that the wallet would eat coins, he advised users to backup their wallets regardless. The context discusses the minimum storage quota of 550 MiB required for pruning nodes in Bitcoin. The user questions why this is necessary if block data is not served to other nodes, and suggests that the client could just do transaction verification and relaying, keeping only the blocks being verified on disk. The code comments reveal that the reason for the minimum storage quota is to allow reorgs up to 288 blocks deep even when pruning. It is important to note that while release notes are not meant as a replacement or supplement for documentation, the documentation for -prune is available. It is also crucial to understand that the minimum storage quota of 550 MiB is necessary for pruning nodes even if the block data is not served to other nodes. If a client did transaction verification and transaction relaying and only kept the block(s) being verified on disk, it could result in deleting security-relevant transaction data if N is not set high enough.
